metadata.title: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome in Children and Adolescents
synonyms: pain syndrome, regional complex in children and adolescents
pain syndrome, complex regional in children and adolescents, rsd
anatomical location body part affected: Usually initially occurs at a distal site of the affected extremity; however, complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) can progress to affect multiple joints in one extremity, most often not in a specific dermatome
description: A disorder that most commonly involves severe spontaneous pain and multiple system dysfunctions, including musculoskeletal, integumentary, neurological, vascular, and psychological. CRPS presents with varying degrees of severity or duration that is significantly disproportionate to the amount of pain expected from the initiating event/injury(12,29)
Complex  – denotes the complex nature of the pain response, which may include inflammation and autonomic, cutaneous,motor, and dystrophic changes(12)
Regional  – wide distribution of symptoms beyond area of the original injury(12)

Pain  – is the primary characteristic of this syndrome(12) –In 1993 the International Association for the Study of Pain special interest section, Pain and Sympathetic Nervous System, proposed a new classification system for reflex sympathetic dystrophy (RSD) and causalgia in order to facilitate more accurate diagnosis and treatment -CRPS I:  severe, deep, burning pain that is out of proportion to the injury without discernible nerve injury. Formally known as RSD. This Clinical Review  primarily addresses CRPS I -CRPS II:  same as CRPS I but with the presence of major peripheral nerve injury(29)

When comparing CRPS in children and adults(33) –There is a larger sex gap in children, with the female to male ratio up to 6:1 –The disease is more common in the lower extremity in children –The long-term  prognosis is much more favorable in children

ICD-10 codes.G56.4: complex regional pain syndrome II of upper limb
ICD-10 codes.G56.7: complex regional pain syndrome II of lower limb
ICD-10 codes.G90.5: complex regional pain syndrome I (CRPS I)
ICD-10 codes.M89.0: algoneurodystrophy (ICD 10 codes are provided for reader reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Three stages of CRPS(12) –Stage I – Traumatic/acute stage – onset to 3 months -Characterized by pain, pitting edema, discoloration, hyperalgesia/allodynia –Stage II – Dystrophic stage – 3 to 6 months after initial onset -Characterized by pain, brawny edema, stiffness, redness, heat, bony demineralization, shiny skin, hyperalgesia/allodynia -Pain typically peaks in this stage –Stage III – Atrophic stage – 6 months to years after initial onset -Characterized by joint thickening, joint contractures, hard swelling that is often unresponsive to treatment, substantial loss of function within the involved extremity, skin that is cool, pale, and dry -Pain typically subsides in this stage
contraindications precautions to test: Be aware of any red flags such as sudden weight loss/gain, signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), dizziness, or bowel or bladder dysfunction that warrant referral to physician or stopping evaluation/treatment

Be aware that clinical signs and symptoms vary greatly and differ significantly in children/adolescents vs adults(27) –Clinical signs tend to be more impressive in children vs adults(27) –Children typically present without overt autonomic signs(27) –Children are more likely to have multiple sites of pain(27) –Children may present with incongruent affects related to reported pain; may report 10/10 pain yet still have an expressionless face(27) –Most often affects the lower extremity in children vs the upper extremity in adults(27,33)

It is extremely important to respect the patient’s self-reported level of pain at all times and recognize that the pain is real and significant; pain should be acknowledged. This is reassuring to the patient because family members, peers, and healthcare professionals may think she/he is malingering(24,25,27)

It is crucial to conduct the initial evaluation in the most minimally threatening manner in hopes of limiting future anxiety and resistance to treatment intervention. This is especially critical with the pediatric population and goes hand in hand with building trust between the therapist and the patient. Primary caregivers should ideally be present during the evaluation
Most characteristic of this syndrome is allodynia; therefore, be conscious of this when performing the physical evaluation. The slightest movement can cause extreme pain

causes: Most likely multifactorial.Typically there is no correlation between severity of initial injury and intensity of resultingsymptoms

Typically, an injury to an extremity (e.g., sprain, fracture, laceration), medical procedure (e.g., venipuncture), or surgicalprocedure (e.g., carpal tunnel release) precedes the onset of CRPS.(2,29) In many children the triggering factor is injury,illness, and/or psychological distress in any combination, unlike in adults, in whom surgery or myocardial infarction oftenprecedes the onset of CRPS(16,27)
pathogenesis: The exact pathogenesis of CRPS is unknown. There is no single or specific biological cause identified or pathogenesisdescribed(16,19,29)

Theories include:–The functioning of the sympathetic nervous system (which regulates pain) is impaired–Over time, peripheral pain receptors acquire a heightened sensitivity to circulating catecholamines (i.e., fight-or-flighthormones)–Alterations in pain-signaling  pathways-Sensitization of pain projection neurons in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord may:-lower the firing threshold to a stimulus and as a result distort normal stimuli into pain-increase the response to a stimulus and as a result distort normal stimuli into pain–There is increasing neuroimaging evidence of neurological changes (e.g., central sensitization, small fiber changes)in patients with CRPS, which may be associated with a lower pain threshold and increase pain duration, intensity, andlocation. In addition, abnormal activation in the sensory cortex, motor cortex, and emotional processing areas is seen withstimulation of the affected limb compared to the unaffected limb-Reorganization of the primary somatosensory cortex, the secondary somatosensory cortex, and the motor cortex can beseen on neuroimaging(28)–Activation of the immune system may be a factor, but this has primarily been studied in adult populations, with theexception of case reports of CRPS following vaccinations in pediatric patients(31)
risk factors: Predisposing factors in children/adolescents–Sex: Most likely to occur in females(16)–Age: Mean onset is around 12 years of age(16)–Psychological-Stressful event;(2) most researchers agree that psychological stress and minor trauma play a significant role in childrenwho develop CRPS(24)-Some studies indicate that children who are classified as overachievers and/or have a low pain threshold may bepredisposed to CRPS; however, others question whether maladaptive traits and coping styles are developed in responseto the chronic, intense pain of CRPS(16,27)-In children and adolescents, psychosocial factors may also be related to the developmental stage of this population andmay exacerbate CRPS(27)–Genetics: Children and adolescents who have relatives with chronic pain conditions are more susceptible to CRPS. Theremay be a genetic predisposition to CRPS(16)–Trauma: often a minor injury (such as a sprain, strain, or bruise) precedes the development of CRPS-Period of inactivity or immobilization following this initial injury (constrictive dressings, splints, casts)-Trauma preceding CRPS occurs in < 50% of cases in children and adolescents-Often the patient cannot recall a specific event due the triviality of the initial injury and the elapsed time prior to thedevelopment of CRPS symptoms(25)–Other: Local cold injury, revascularization of an ischemic injury, or postoperative wound(25)

This is reassuring to the patient because family members, peers, and healthcare professionals may think she/he is malingering(24,25,27)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Clinicians should inquire about inciting event/injury and signs/symptoms patient has experienced up to the present time -Pain complaints can start within hours to weeks of the inciting event/injury and last well beyond expected time of recovery -LE is much more likely to be involved in children vs. UE in adults(27,33) of injuryobjectively measures skin temperature changes, which are often inconsistent with findings of the contralateral limbdocuments abnormal resting and evoked sweat production. Increased resting sweat output and decreased quantitative sudomotor axon reflex test compared to the contralateral side may beusefulin diagnosing CRPSlimited value for diagnosis and treatment since CRPS is not always sympathetically induced; should not be used to confirm or rule out CRPS diagnosis(27)Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative/ complementary therapies (e.g., acupuncture, herbal supplements) and whether they were helpful with symptom reliefDocument whether patient has had any rehabilitation services for this condition and what specific treatment interventions were helpful or not, such as TENS, aquatic therapy, or contrast baths. Has the patient received or is going to be receiving psychological/behavioral therapy?

course of treatment.medical management: Average time to diagnose CRPS is 912  months following the initial injury(27) Diagnosis may be delayed due to limited abilities of children to describe their symptoms and the infrequency of presentation in children (< 12 years of age) Document interventions that have been aimed at treating pain and/or disability. Patients are frequently referred from one medical health professional to another in an attempt to diagnose and treat their pain and other symptoms. This often includes prescribing patients with medications for pain management and diagnostic tests (see common medications and diagnostic tests sections, below) Local anesthetic sympathetic nerve blockade is commonly used to treat CRPS; however, there is limited evidence to support its use(30) Regional anesthetic techniques, including peripheral nerve catheters or sympathetic blockade, have been used with varying degrees of success(32) Ozone therapy is being explored as an alternative nonpharmacologic treatment for CRPS(38)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? No specific pharmacologic treatmentshave been established for the pediatric population. Over-the-counter  medications (e.g., NSAIDS, paracetamol) may be used. There are reports of amitriptyline, phenytoin, and antiepileptic drugs (e.g., gabapentin) providing some patients with some improvement. There are no clinical studies on the use of antidepressants and CRPS. There is no definitive evidence supporting the use of antiinflammatory  drugs as the firstline of pharmacologic intervention(33) Common medications prescribedNSAIDs, corticosteroids, tramadol (corticosteroids in children have shown very little benefit and due to the potential side effects should be avoided)(25,27)amitriptyline, doxepin, nortriptyline, trazodone(27)carbamazepine, gabapentin, phenytoin(27)mexiletine(27) Bisphosphonatescalcitonin injections(27)hydromorphone, morphine, oxycodone(27) Opioids may be useful in the acute stages for pain management; however, the use of opioids for chronic pain management is controversial(29)clonidine patch, phentolamine, epidural blocks, guanethidine, bretylium, calcium channel blockers, betablockers,  alpha-blockers  (in children, generally produce short-term  pain improvement or no benefit and may be associated with adverse effects and therefore should be avoided)(25,27)clonazepam, baclofen (intrathecal baclofen may improve dystonia in selected patients but there are adverse effects such as somnolence, urinary retention, muscle weakness)(27)capsaicin cream, lidocaine transdermal(27)  Topical ketamine can reduce CRPS pain and central sensitization. Studies suggest topical ketamine can rescue allodynia and hyperalgesia but does not help with pain. IV ketamine may also be administered(31)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  No test or procedure conclusively confirms or rules out the presence of CRPS.(27) Laboratory tests and diagnostic imaging (MRI, CT scan, and ultrasound) are often nonspecific, inconclusive, and not necessary or useful. Negative tests do not exclude CRPS. Tests should be done more to rule out other potential causes. There are several diagnostic criteria for CRPS (e.g., International Association for the Study of Pain, Budapest Criteria) but they are not validated for use in pediatric populations(16)
Focal demineralization is a notable radiographic feature.(29) Osteoporosis can be observed in the later stages of CRPS, with disuse as a contributing factor(2)
Technetium bone scan may reveal reduced blood flow and decreased uptake in the affected extremity; however,
normal scan does not rule out CRSP. Poor intraobserver  reliability; estimated to wrongly diagnose CRPS in 20% of cases and fail to diagnose 27% of CRPS cases(25,27)

Thermography: records differences in radiant heat-emission  patterns between extremities. It can detect sensory nerve root irritation in conditions such as CRPS that do not typically conform to a dermatomal pain distribution. Asymmetrical color variations are a reflection of abnormal sympathetic function and can be recorded within 72 hours

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Do any situations seem to make symptoms better or worse? Document length of time prior to exacerbating/alleviating symptoms -Factors that often aggravate patients’ pain are temperature changes, active and passive movement of involved extremity, light pressure from clothing or air currents, emotional distress or excitement
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms -Pain does not necessarily remain in a specific dermatome or peripheral nerve pattern -Pain tends to spread proximally to involve the entire extremity or ipsilateral quadrant of the body but rarely to other regions of the body or contralateral extremity(27)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling, severe, throbbing) -Pain is present in 98% of cases(25) -The longer the patient experiences CRPS, the more complex the pain becomes(27)allows patients to describe their pain in three dimensions (sensory, affective, and evaluative) with a composite pain rating index score. It assists patients with specifying their subjective pain(17)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  numeric scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the present moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much) -It is important to note that children often have incongruent affect when reporting severe pain; for example, they may state they have 10/10 pain on a V AS with a cheerful smile on their face.(24) Numeric scales are valid only for children who have basic numerical competency(15) self-report  pain V AS or photographic scale developed for children 318 years of age, and studied primarily for acute or postoperative pain(15) -Minimum clinically significant difference in V AS for children 815  years is 1 cm(5) -V AS for pain rating (010  line) has weak recommendations for use in chronic pain for patients ages 618(15)children are asked to rate pain on a scale from 0 to 11. Weak recommendation for use in children ages 818(15)10-item  V AS tool developed to assess distinct pain qualities associated with neuropathic pain such as onset of pain, location of pain, characteristics of pain, severity of pain, and associated symptoms
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables (e.g., prolonged sitting or standing, barefoot vs socks and shoes)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night due to pain or discomfort
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ordizziness, bowel/bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia) -Does the patient report altered skin temperature differences between extremities? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: There is a greater risk for recurrence of CRPS in patients who do not receive psychological intervention as part of therapeutic treatment(25)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, attention disorders, musculoskeletal injuries, and orthopedic disorders. In addition, inquire whether there is a family history of chronic pain, chronic illnesses, fibromyalgia, or mental health conditions
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs). In 2010, the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons recommended that individuals be prescribed a 50day  regimen of daily vitamin C (at least 50mg), to begin immediately after upper extremity trauma or extremity surgery including the distal radius, hand, wrist, foot, and ankle to assist with prevention of CRPS(29)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about any other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient attend school? Has the patient stopped participating in physical education or other forms of exercise? Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports and have those activities been limited due to patient’s current condition? Does the patient have hobbies or special interests? Does the patient participate ingroup activities such as a religious group, Boy/Girl Scouts, etc.? Does the patient have a job; if so, what are his/her work duties? Do the patient and family have a strong support network?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -Is the patient currently requiring the use of assistive devices or equipment in order to perform self-care  activities, such as a walker, cane, elevated commode, grab bars, reachers? -CRPS can be exacerbated by immobilization, as with the use of a splint, cast, or crutches(25,27)
social and occupational history.living environment: With whom does the patient live (family members, caregivers, etc.)? Identify if there are any barriers within the home for patient’s independenceStairs? If so, number of floors in home? Location of bedroom and bathroom? Entrance to the home? Shower vs bathtub?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Is the patient currently using an assistive device such as a cane, walker, or wheelchair due to musculoskeletal weakness and/or decreased cardiorespiratory endurance? Does the patient have orthotics/splints to prevent joint contractures? Determine if patient is using devices correctly and assess fit of orthotics/splints. Immobilization is considered detrimental to the patient’s recovery and should be immediately addressed(27)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess patient’s static and dynamic balance with one or more of the following tests as deemed appropriate per –Timed Up and Go (TUG) test,(23)Bruininks-Oseretsky  Test of Motor Proficiency, Second Edition (BOT-2)  balance subscale,(7,37) Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS)(8) –Due to time constraints, parts of the PBS such as Romberg, Sharpened Romberg, and Single Leg Stance may be performed
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Utilize the 6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT), a submaximal exercise test requiring the use of the Modified Borg Scale(10)
May also report patient’s level of exertion using a dyspnea scale
May also monitor heart rate (HR), blood pressure (BP), and oxygen saturation pre and post activity
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Palpate distal pulses –Vasomotor changes present in 67% of cases(25) –Decreased circulation causes the extremity to become cool and pale(12)Perform dermatome/myotome testing for UEs, LEs as indicated. Compare affected extremity to unaffected extremity –CRPS tends to spread beyond peripheral nerve distributions(12)Assess basic ADLs and level of assistance required to safely and independently perform skills such as transfers, bed mobility, grooming, dressing, and toileting as indicated –Use the WeeFIM,(21) TUG test,(23) Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition (PDMS-2),(22) Pediatric Evaluation of Disability Inventory (PEDI),(6,36) Functional Disability Inventory (FDI)(36) and/or BOT-2(7,37) as appropriate per patient’s age and setting
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess patient’s gait and note any significant deviations or assistive devicesAssess UE and LE joint integrity. Are there any joint capsule restrictions? Is the patient at risk for and/or already developing UE or LE joint contractures? –Joint contractures and joint thickening are possible complications in patients with stage III CRPS(12)Assess UE and LE muscle tone as indicated and note any asymmetry such as muscle spasms, dystonia, tremors, and the inability to initiate movement in the affected extremity(4) –Movement disorders (e.g., tremor, jerking, fixed dystonic postures)are seen in 15%–20%  of cases. The etiology of these findings is not known, with several theories being studied(4)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Perform bilateral myotomal testing for upper and lower extremity as indicated. Assess trunk and abdominal strength through manual muscle testing (MMT). Note asymmetry and whether MMT reproduces patient’s primary complaints and/or the patient’s strength is limited by painHave parent/primary caregiver complete gross and fine motor checklist (e.g., age skill acquired such as sitting upright, rolling, ambulating independently, feeding self, writing) to establish patient’s baseline motor development –May use assessment tools, such as the PEDI, PDMS-2,  and BOT-2 –Isolated gross or fine motor skills may be performed to assess age-appropriate  functional level (e.g., jumping, throwing/ catching, grasping objects) as indicated by medical status
observation inspection palpation includi: Skin color: may be red or pale depending on stage of involvement
Skin temperature: may objectively measure temperature change with a skin temperature probe or infrared thermometer. Children tend to present with a cold involved extremity(19,27)
Sudomotor changes: hyperhidrosis (excessive sweating), less often present in children vs adults(27)

Trophic changes: increased/decreased hair growth, increased/decreased nail growth, brittle nails, thinning/thickening skin, shiny skin(19,29) -Children are less likely to develop trophic change than are adults(27)

Document the presence of edema. Swelling is common and typically diffuse, not isolated to joints(11) -Note if the edema is localized, diffuse, pitting, nonpitting, or brawny(12) -May use the Pitting Edema Scale and take girth measurements
May present with muscle atrophy in involved extremity due to disuse(19)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Visual inspection of patient’s sitting and standing posture and note any abnormalities/asymmetries
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess AROM and PROM for UE, LE, and trunk and note asymmetry. Note if any of these motions reproducespatient’s primary complaints and/or ROM is limited by pain –Decreased ROM is present in ~ 75% of cases(25) –Muscle guarding due to pain and contractures interferes with ROM(19)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess bilateral C5, C6, C7, L4, and S1 and note any abnormality. Reflexes should also be assessed. Changes may or may not be related to CRPS(29)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Perform light touch, sharp-dull,  and joint proprioception testing for bilateral UE and LE and note any asymmetry present in the affected extremity and whether testing reproduces patient’s primary complaints. May also include tolerance to scratching, temperature, and vibration –Common symptoms are allodynia or hyperalgesia –Patients often report severe pain in response to light touch such as pressure of a sheet
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Health-related  quality of life measures should be included due to the potential impact of CRPS on children’s physical, psychological, and social lives -Child Health Questionnaire (CHQ) -Health profile specifically developed for children and adolescents; short form and full-length -Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (Peds-QL)(14) -Valid and reliable quality of life tool for children and adolescents ; includes school functioning subscale -5-point  scale; higher the score, the greater the disability -Patient Specific Functional Scale (PSFS) -Fear Avoidance Beliefs Questionnaire (FABQ) -Functional Disability Index (FDI)(14) -Valid and reliable test consisting of 15 items concerning perceptions of physical and psychosocial functioning during the past 2 weeks -Total scores range from 0 to 60, with higher scores indicating greater disabilitydeveloped to assess functional impairment in 3 domains -Patient rates the extent to which work/school, social life, and family life are impaired by his/her symptoms on a 10-point  V AS(13)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Patient’s affect may be altered due to current medications patient may be taking as well as other diagnoses (e.g., attention deficit disorder [ADD], ADHD, sensory integration dysfunction)

electrotherapy contraindications precaut: Stimulation through or across the chest
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
Open wounds without proper occlusive dressings
Anxiety or fear of the water
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with CRPS may be at risk for falls depending on the severity of their symptoms, especially if the lower extremity is involved; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies
Immobilization of the affected joint is detrimental to the patient’s recovery. Early mobilization is key. This should be stressed immediately to the patient and family/caregivers(25,27)

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and physician’s orders. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

It is in the best interest of the patient to be evaluated and treated by an experienced pediatric physical therapist who also specializes in treating children and adolescents with chronic pain disorders. It is important to understand overall developmental stages from a physical and cognitive level in order to maximize individualized treatment sessions

Children with chronic pain syndromes may have ineffective coping strategies, anxiety, and perceived lower competence, and they are often perfectionists who set high goals. These behavioral traits can significantly impact physical therapy treatment sessions and need to be taken into account when developing treatment sessions, goals, and home programs(18)

Electrotherapy contraindications/precautions include: (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician, electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(34)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The earlier CRPS is diagnosed and rehabilitation intervention initiated, the greater likelihood for positive outcomes and minimizing disability(16,19,25,27)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Other diagnoses should be ruled out by the treating physician prior to the initiation of physical therapy for CRPS(25,27) –Chronic arterial insufficiency: pulses are chronically diminished or absent; variable with CRPS –Raynaud’s disease: episodic skin color changes (typically white to blue to red pattern) in the distal extremity often aggravated by cold and pain –Phlebothrombosis: no associated hyperesthesia or vasomotor changes –Rheumatic disorders: such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or rheumatoid arthritis, which is associated with abnormal lab tests; CRPS usually presents with normal lab work, including normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate, normal C-reactive  protein, and lack of elevated autoimmune antibodies –Infections (cellulitis, osteomyelitis, infectious arthritis): CRPS does not present with fever or leukocytosis
prognosis: Diagnosis and therapeutic treatment intervention for CRPS within the first 3–6 months after onset is the single best prognostic indicator(25,27)
Children have greater plasticity of the nervous system and higher levels of growth hormones, which appear to have a healing effect on the nerves and modulate pain(9,27)

Appropriate support from primary caregivers is crucial for a child’s full recovery. Maladaptive parental behavior (e.g., protective behavior) may be decreased with cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)(18)

Prognosis for short-term  improvement with physical therapy alone is good; however, there is a significant risk that CRPS will recur if psychological and/or CBT intervention is not included in treatment intervention(25)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: A multidisciplinary rehabilitation team approach to treatment is the key to improving outcomes in children and adolescents with CRPS.(39) If the patient is not already being followed by a multidisciplinary team, referrals may be needed to all or the followingin order to maximize the patient’s recovery: pain management specialist, occupational therapist, psychologist, orthopedist, pain management specialist, and physiatrist. Treatment interventions in addition to physical therapy are CBT, psychotherapy, spinal cord stimulation, sympathetic nerve block, and sympathectomy (generally not recommended due to high rate of pain and symptom recurrence after 6–12  months). Referral to a mental health professional is of particular importance for the patient and caregiver(16,27,39) There is a greater risk for recurrence of CRPS without psychological intervention(25) –It is well documented that there is a large psychosocial component in pediatric patients with chronic pain. In some children who develop chronic pain syndromes there is likely an interplay between genetic predisposition andpsychosocial factors(18) –Patients need to learn positive coping strategies and avoid negative behaviors(27) –Discussing psychological stress as a potential cause is vital because this allows parents to express their concern about the role stress plays in their child’s pain(24) –Common psychosocial factors that affect a child’s ability to deal with chronic pain include real and imagined losses and fears, pain threshold, preferred coping strategy, and dependency level within their family(27) –Common psychological treatment interventions that have found to be beneficial are biofeedback, relaxation methods, self-hypnosis,  and distraction techniques(27) –Recurring psychological themes observed in a prospective study of patients with CRPS I who participated in an intense exercise therapy program were lack of verbalization or recognition of feelings, parental enmeshment with child, difficulty individuating from extremely close families, and the presence of unsupportive, noncohesive families(24) Several studies indicate that psychological symptoms related to CRPS are a result and not a cause of the disorder(4,27) –Depression and anxiety are common results of chronic pain(27) –Researchers in the Italy found that motor disorders seen in CRPS I are not associated with sensorimotor plasticity and are more closely aligned with psychogenic dystonia versus idiopathic dystonia(4) CRPS in the pediatric population impacts the patient as well as parents and family, resulting in high-stress  relationships and often decreased parental coping(1) –Online forums may provide parents with support, information, and advice  –Researchers found that there may be opportunity for healthcare providers to provide caregiver support that addresses emotional, physical, and information needs of caregivers –Overall family life and everyday activities can be significantly impacted. Caregiver support services and counseling can be of benefit and may be augmented by online forums
other considerations: It is very unlikely that children and adolescents with neurological diseases such as peripheral neuropathy, tumors, or stroke will develop CRPS(25) –However, researchers in Canada reported a case study in which a 15-year-old  male developed CRPS-1  in his upper extremity after experiencing an idiopathic subdural hemorrhagic stroke(35)

It is extremely important to build trust with the patient in order to maximize his or her active participation, allow for patient’s perception of control during therapy sessions, and enhance potential rehabilitation outcome (27)

In addition to building trust with the patient, physical therapists need to learn how to distract the patient while he/she is participating in therapy sessions in order to maximize tolerance to treatment sessions, deemphasize pain, and emphasize function (i.e., Ask “how much have you been able to do this week?” vs. “How is your pain?”). Physical therapists need to initiate desensitization treatments early so that the patient can understand that the treatment is not going to permanently hurt him/her. Building trust with the patient can assist with reducing the patient’s fear of treatment interventions (e.g., functional mobility with the use of the involved extremity)(18)

Somatic problems,anxiety or depressive symptoms, impaired emotional decision-making,  and decreased working memory and ability to perform conditioning activitiesare often seen in children and adolescents with chronic pain(3)

Research investigating the safety and efficacy of spinal cord stimulation (SCS) in children with CRPS is ongoing, but additional research is needed(26) –Authors of a case report present successful use of SCS in a 17-year-old  patient with a 6-year  history of CRPS I
treatment summary: Based on a meta-analysis  of 19 systematic reviews of the effectiveness of any therapeutic intervention used to reduce pain, disability, or both, researchers concluded there is a significant lack of high-quality  evidence for the effectiveness of most therapies for CRPS in adults; however, this meta-analysis  did not include pediatric studies. Evidence-based  literature regarding treatment interventions to manage CRPS for both adults and children is limited and larger clinical trials need to be conducted(20)

Physical therapy is the cornerstone of the multidisciplinary treatment approach, with the overall goal of restoring function. Greatest priority should be placed on immediate initiation of physical therapy(33) and, if needed, occupational therapy in conjunction with psychological/behavioral counseling in order to improve patient’s outcome(25,27) –5–6 hours of aggressive, multidisciplinary therapy (physical therapy, occupational therapy, and CBT) is often required vs. only 1–2 hours a day in order to be most effective(27) –Generally, as the patient’s function improves his or her pain decreases(25) –Most children do well without any intervention other than physical therapy consisting of desensitization therapy and continued use and mobilization of the extremity. CBT is also encouraged(33)
It should be emphasized to the patient and family/caregivers that the prognosis is good with treatment intervention in children in whom CRPS is diagnosed(25)
Therapeutic goals should be clearly defined and accepted by the patient at the initial evaluation and reviewed on a regular basis throughout treatment interaction(25)
Some researchers strongly encourage parents not to be present during therapy sessions because they can unintentionally undermine the therapist’s authority and distract the patient(24)

In general, the treatment approach for children should emphasize restored functional mobility, patient education, pain relief, and psychological support as needed through exercise therapy and physical modalities vs. prescriptive medications(24,25) –It is believed that intensive exercise is effective in reducing pain and restoring function by inhibiting the sympathetic stimulation, increasing circulation, and stimulating the release of endorphins(27)

Exercise therapy should include one-to-one  therapist–patient interaction, a focus on function, acknowledging but disregarding pain, and prolonged duration(24) –The patient’s pain and discomfort levels often increase at the initiation of treatment but can be addressed effectively with distraction techniques (e.g., playing catch while jumping on the trampoline, playing computer/board games while standing on one leg, races and competition games)(24,27) –Anticipate major reluctance on the patient to fully engage in initial treatment session; the therapist’s attitude should be firm but non-punitive(25) –Provide choices for the patient to make throughout therapy sessions so that he or she shares responsibility and takes ownership in treatment. For example, have the patient choose between two treatment activities (trampoline jumping or standing on one leg)(25) –TENS is one of the most common physical therapy modalities used to assist with decreasing patient pain and has been found to be more effective in children than adults(12,27) -Efficacy is well-documented  as a therapeutic intervention for pain control(12) -Intervention should not exceed 60 min. at a time for pain management(27) -May be beneficial to maintain a TENS diary indicating patient’s pain level on a scale of 1 to 10 pre and post TENS use, as well as any activities thought to have exacerbated the pain(27) -TENS use should be tapered as the pain-free  periods throughout the day increase(12)

Researchers at Children’s Hospital Boston conducted a prospective, longitudinal study to evaluate clinical outcomes of an interdisciplinary day-hospital  program for children with CRPS(14) –Fifty-six  children (mean age 14 years, 89.3% females) with CRPS who failed to progress sufficiently with a previous outpatient and/or inpatient treatments –Subjects participated in daily (5 days/week) physical therapy, occupational therapy, and psychological treatment for 8 hours/day with an equal emphasis on physical therapy and CBT approaches to pain management. Medical and nursing care was provided as needed. Individualized home exercise programs were also included –The median duration of stay was 3 weeks with post treatment follow-up  at a median of 10 months after discharge –Pain intensity, functional disability, subjective report of limb function, timed running, occupational performance, medication use, use of assistive devices, and emotional functioning (anxiety and depression) statistically and clinically improved from admission to discharge. Functional gains were maintained or further improved at follow-up –A day-hospital  multidisciplinary model offers an alternative rehabilitation approach that is less costly than inpatient rehabilitation but still intensive enough to benefit children who fail to progress with traditional outpatient treatment

Researchers at Children’s Hospital in Seattle, Washington, conducted a prospective study on the short-term  and long-term effects of an intensive exercise therapy program for children with CRPS I(24) –One hundred and three children were initially followed (mean age 13 years, 87% females) –Most received 4 hours of aerobic functionally directed exercises, 1–2 hours of hydrotherapy, and desensitization each day with a mean duration of 14 days either as an inpatient, outpatient, or home-based  patient –The majority of the patients were compliant with their exercise regimens –No medications or modalities (TENS, acupuncture) were used except occasionally acetaminophen for headaches –All patients underwent an initial psychological screening evaluation; 77% were referred for psychological counseling –92% of patients had complete resolution of pain and return of full function –Median time between remission of the first episode of CRPS and the start of the second episode was 2 months

Researchers of a case study reported on a 14-year-old  female who injured the dorsum of her foot by dropping school textbooks on it(27) –A neurologist diagnosed CRPS 1 week later; the subject had no emotional or psychiatric symptoms or disorders. For 10 weeks, unsuccessful treatment included carbamazepine, verapamil, lidocaine transdermal patches, physical therapy for 1 hour, 3x week, 2 sympathetic nerve blocks, home hydrotherapy, nortriptyline, gabapentin, 4 epidural blocks, and narcotic painkillers –Pain and symptoms progressively worsened to the state of wheelchair confinement, assistance with transfers, measurable edema, pain throughout the entire extremity, and skin temperature changes –The patient was admitted to the A.I. duPont Hospital for Children in Delaware, United States, and underwent 5–6 hours a day of intensive physical therapy, occupational therapy, and CBT for 1 month (desensitization, distraction, self-hypnosis, exercise, and functional activities)  –Within 3 days the subject was walking and by the end of the first week she no longer had neuropathic pain. All medication was weaned prior to discharge –Symptoms recurred periodically since discharge but have subsided quickly with the treatment modalities learned from the inpatient rehab program . maintenance or prevention: Patients need to be able to independently manage their pain and dysfunction without the need of professional attention through a well-designed multidisciplinary therapeutic home program. This ultimately places the control into the patient’s hands and may help improve long-term outcomes(24)

CRPS is much easier to prevent than treat, meaning that even after a mild to moderate trauma or injury it is imperative that early and effective analgesia is provided. Early mobilization after injury or surgery reduces the likelihood of developing CRPS. Emphasis should be on restoring active motion and seeking professional guidance from a physical therapist sooner than later
Patients should be instructed on desensitization techniques to assist in preventing the development of CRPS after an injury or trauma
There is a significant risk that CRPS will recur if CBT or other psychological intervention is not included in treatment intervention(25)
It is important for patients to continue with their home program even after they have been discharged from direct physical or occupational therapy
